commentBody:
"How'd you do on your primatology exam?"
"Great! Got an ape plus!"

(Sorry for gibbon you that one.)
Lovely theme! Didn't even notice the ASYMMETRY till I filled out ASYMMETRY lol

Before starting the puzzle, I spent a little bit of time trying to find symmetry in the black squares. If I just fold the puzzle this way . . . or that way . . . nope! So finishing the puzzle and seeing the overlay show up was definitely entertaining.

Other than that, SALMONBERRY? That's a new one for me.
The overlay reveal at the end was really cool.
Unnecessary theme. Only saw it after finishing the whole thing.

So we are going to have consecutive puzzles from a married pair of constructors. 

I‚Äôm girding myself for some manner of callback to today‚Äôs grid.

This is a great example of a puzzle where you don‚Äôt need to get the theme to solve it, but when you do, it‚Äôs a delightful surprise. Lovely constructor note ‚Äî looking forward to tomorrow‚Äôs puzzle.
Second TATI!

This Tuesday was less direct than you'd usually expect for a Tuesday.  Not all that hard, 16 minute solve for me, but had a few vexing corners.

For example, I thought 31A initially was LEOTARD rather than UNITARD which made the down clues confusing.  And there's some long crosses like ONTHEDL where until you get it, the letters you see next to each other makes you think you got a cross clue wrong.

I actually said WHOA when I finished and the A lit up. Nice. 

Also yay for cog sci getting a mention! That was my major in college (under a different name though)
Made it through but, boy, that felt like a really tough Tuesday.
I give this one an A.  Just because.
Took me awhile to get into this one. But it was fun. I have never heard of a salmonberry. I had several missteps with that one. Thanks, Kevin!
First time I‚Äôve left a comment although I‚Äôve been a fan of NYT puzzles and this column for ages. And I just wanted to say, brilliant!
Cool grid!

This deserves a A+ for constructive creativity. I shall BLEAT it from the mountaintop. No keeping it ON THE Down Low. 
üëçüèºüëçüèº 2 thumbs up from me
Thanks, Kevin üòé

Happy Tuesday!
What a nice surprise.

!!!

Whoa, indeed!

üòâ

Yours,

Astonished Out West

Felt like a really tough Tuesday, but somehow finished under average time - another piece of evidence that subjective feelings are not too helpful when it comes to rating how hard these puzzles are objectively. 

The asymmetry theme was awfully clever - I appreciate it and I'm grateful that I didn't need to figure it out as an additional puzzle to finish the puzzle itself. (Making us figure out the theme seems like it should be reserved for Thursdays.)
A much harder Tuesday than usual.  Liked the puzzle a lot though.

Ha! Funny theme... especially for those playing on the app. 60A reminded me of the 1991 film "Salmonberries," starring k.d. lang, and her gorgeous song "Barefoot." https://youtu.be/FqzyBlF9Q8k?si=g5ZUUwkQZFvTU_L8
Very impressive!!
Can anyone explain the midi today 25D clue fate/answer fate
We once had a sweet orange-and-white male cat named (not by us) ‚ÄúTom.‚Äù  To our certain knowledge he was never a parent.  His memory tripped me up in this puzzle, but I fixed it!

Loved it. Impressive creation.

Also interesting because for me it was a cakewalk, but many others, judging by the comments, found it difficult. Other days I take a beating and come here to find comments calling it easy. I have no grander point but to say that I find the differences in human minds fascinating.
With just the NO at 56-down, my first thought was ‚Äúnoob‚Äù in lieu of ‚Äúbaby‚Äù. Funny where the mind goes!

Very clever! If I weren't playing on the app, I doubt I would have figured out the "A" SYMMETRY theme. I could be extra picky and note that the T in BLEAT and the S in SALES technically disrupt the perfect continuity of the As, but I imagine finding a word that ended in AA (Kwanzaa?) and a word that began in AA (Aardvark?), is just too much to hope for. But seriously, an outstanding Tuesday!

Brilliantly constructed ‚Äî and a great solve. I really, really enjoyed it. 

I got tripped up at the end by the NW corner for the silliest of reasons. I had  AftER for [In line with], which gave me PROUDtAtAS, a nod to the multilingual among us, I thought. Then I wracked my brain for The ECONO_IFT, seriously considering ECONOgIFT for awhile, even though‚Ä¶ I subscribe to it. 

Did I mention I‚Äôm sleep-deprived today?

Again, a brilliant Tuesday. Thanks, Kevin.
Great puzzle‚Äô
Didn‚Äôt know that it was Jacque Tati Week for the crossword.
Last I checked, BLONDE is an adjective... https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/blond https://www.oed.com/dictionary/blonde_adj?tl=true

Had SEmi before SELF in the NW, which gave mIEn before LIEU.  

After getting SING for 8A, for a hot second I thought the largest human muscle was going to be GSPOT. üòÑ

This was great! Super clever and the difficulty was right in line with my usual Tuesdays. I'll admit I didn't notice the "A" SYMMETRY until I completed the puzzle, but when it popped up I went "ooooh!" 

My favorite clues were SALMONBERRY and ON THE DL.
Aaargh!

That was fun, though apparently I'm not sure how to spell ASYMMETRY. People solving online should make sure Show Overlays is turned on in their settings, and here's the solved puzzle from xwordinfo.com, which shows the surprise when the puzzle's finished. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/26/2025
Brilliant!
...Was scratching my head as to the full meaning of the theme clue until the very end, when the graphic revealed all. Fantastic!  Great puzzle.

So much to like! It felt like the hardest Monday puzzle I can remember, but in the end I finished in below average time. The apex area really hung me up, what with two unknown proper names. TEA TREE, VDAY, SALMON BERRY, so many new to me entries. And then a graphic as good as fireworks. This was fun!
At first I was wondering if they threw this one in because all the expert symmetry-type constructors were out in the Hamptons. Very good! Fun thing it does at the end

2nd attempt past the birds...

Well, for better or worse, after all the "training" here I immediately noticed the little a asymmetry of the grid, and was very happy. I've long maintained that the symmetry "rule" is ill conceived, pointless, and deprives the customers of what might otherwise be delightful puzzles, all for needless artificial conformity. Arbitrary counterproductive frippery, based on nothing but convention for its own sake.  So this was welcome and fresh relief.

On the other hand I missed the intended big A symmetry until the game was complete. Oh well. It was still fine. 

Fast enjoyable puzzle.
Quite a feat of construction. Nicely done. And lovely constructor's notes - made me smile and was a much needed break from all the depressing headlines. Looking forward to the Wednesday puzzle now.
That was a fun Tuesday puzzle with a satisfying resolve. A+

Can't say I noticed the asymmetry until the clue forced me to actually look at the puzzle. Not something I typically do. I noticed the fact that the puzzle was not symmetrical but I didn't see all the A's until the reveal. Fun!

Seemed like really good cluing in this one. I got PROUDPAPAS and ONTHEDL right away on the first pass which makes me think the clues were leading me in that direction.
I smiled :)
Very fun, even brilliant, puzzle, but still sighted ECRU, ERR, EEL...no ANI, ETSY or OREO though!

I am surprised that, at least so far, no-one else got waylaid, as I did ‚Äî or at least bothered to admit it here ‚Äî by concluding that 38A was obviously  ONTHEQT.  It didn‚Äôt help that I had never before heard the expression that was the correct answer.  (TIL)

WOAH indeed! Very impressive. 





Emu
A quick, fun and satisfying, solve! I noticed the asymmetry once the clue prompted. But the best part was the grAnd reveAl at the end!
I loved this puzzle and was in Awe when the magic happened. Can‚Äôt wait for tomorrow‚Äôs puzzle!
Loved the constructor's notes.

Lovely lovely construction and a lot of fun clues for a Tuesday. Have we ever seen husband and wife crossword team with two crosswords on consecutive days before? (I‚Äôll ask again tomorrow).
Only question, does it count that Marilyn wasn‚Äôt a natural blonde? Do we cancel her for colortural misappropriation? (This joke was ‚Äúdo‚Äù or dye).
This puzzle is Art.
What a fun puzzle, and a sweet constructor‚Äôs note! Very excited for tomorrow‚Äôs, now! It‚Äôs a family affair.
The overlay graphic was a spoiler. I didn't have a chance to search the puzzle for the unique feature.
I wAs AmAzed at the creAtivity behind this puzzle. Well done!

I feel like I‚Äôve been A-framed! Completely dazzled by the plot twist! It was like a Dad on a car trip, looking at the map and insisting, with indignant self-confidence, that the street sign definitely, certainly, can‚Äôt be right‚Ä¶

‚ÄúSymmetry? What symmetry? There‚Äôs no symmetry here!‚Äù And‚Ä¶ smack!
My name has 5 As, my undergrad was in cognitive science, and I went to Tufts. This hit home hard. (Sadly, I am not a blonde...)

That felt like a Friday. Almost got completely skunked with the GILA/LIANE crossing. Had a D there, and there other answers that I had less confidence in than dIANE. Wasn't particularly confined in the GODS crossing either. 11 minutes

Phew, I found this pretty tough for a Tuesday. But I got a kick out of the theme and I loved seeing TOAD HALL. It‚Äôs been a long time since I read The Wind In The Willows. A charming funny story about friends, no evil geniuses or saving the world involved (as seems to be the case in most of today‚Äôs movies for kids)

A-mazing. While ASYMMETRY was an obvious answer for part of 66A, I didn‚Äôt get the second part of the clue until the big yellow A appeared. And while I know some solvers find such ‚Äútricks‚Äù indulgent and unnecessary, I am thoroughly impressed by the level of skill it takes to bring this type of vision to life. Especially when the fill is this engaging.

A puzzle doesn‚Äôt have to be just a puzzle. It can also be a work of Art. Thanks for sharing, Mr. Curry.

Fine fine puzzle.  Very original!
Thanks!!!

I loved the elegant theme and the yellow lines forming an A that popped up on my phone after I solved it.   Also, the constructor's notes in the column were great... I'm looking very forward to playing his wife's puzzle on Wednesday.

Such a nice crossword today!

I'm glad I wasn't the only one who hadn't heard of SALMONBERRY. It's non-native and invasive in the UK.

I got caught by the kerb/CURB issue, which held up COGSCI (itself quite tricky for me) and the clue reminded me of the Shel Silverstein poem:

There is a place where the sidewalk ends
And before the street begins.
And there the grass grows soft and bright,
And there the moon-bird rests from his flight
To cool in the peppermint wind.

To me it's nearly incomprehensible to even approach creating a crossword puzzle.

But to then do so with the requirement that all the "A"s in the puzzle make one giant "A"....

...it just beggars belief.  I've never used "beggars belief" before, but it seems just the perfect words for this moment.

My belief is beggared.  That doesn't sound quite as cool, somehow.
Never would have noticed that bit of theme without the app‚Äôs reveal.

Finished this (had to change END to NET to get the right EFFECT) and thought "oh wow, that's cool!"

Didn't notice what was going on while I was solving, but truly a tour-de-force of construction, particularly for a Tuesday. I think this one should go into the "puzzles of the year" file!

Thanks, Mr. Curry!
That was very cool.

Love the creativity, yet there is no symmetry in the final ‚Äòbig A‚Äô figure. Symmetry is balance found in two halves of an object. The ‚Äòbig A‚Äô, however, is not symmetrical because the letter ‚Äòt‚Äô in 39A is not symmetrical with the letter ‚Äòs‚Äô in 42A.   Also, these two characters (not being the letter ‚Äòa‚Äô) are incongruently glommed into the ‚Äòbig A‚Äô. I liked the outside-the-box challenge here especially for a Tuesday, but when symmetry and the letter ‚Äòa‚Äô are the featured aspects of the puzzle, these two shortfalls are, with respect, worthy of note.
Love to see this clever twist on a Tuesday. It felt like the appropriate difficulty. I really liked the way this one comes together. Thanks for the puzzle Kevin!
I never comment on puzzles but this one was exceptional.  Unbelievable skill involved to construct it.  Thank you Kevin!

Felt tough for a Tuesday, but I did love the reveal.
At least I remembered how to spell Ms. Hansen's name.
Very impressive construction and great constuctor note.  I'm looking forward to tomorrow's puzzle.
A great puzzle! is it just me or are Tuesday getting harder?
This puzzle took me 40% longer than average. Maybe I am exaggerating, but it seems like harder than average puzzles on Tuesday has become athing.

A thousand percent of my struggles resulted from my dogged attempts to make the following fit (ahead of ECONOMIST)

 GUARDIANW 
SPECTATOR (at least thjs has the right number of letters)
TIMELSUPP (and its variants)

I literally had to say out loud.... is it possible Londoners live by... the Ecologist?

Delightful theme, but I‚Äôve had preferred the same grid but with much harder clues and the puzzle‚Äôs being released Thursday. 

Great themes merit more time spent, so they should be later in the week. It kind of wastes the theme to relegate it to Tuesday.

WHOA (WOAH). I absolutely did not pick up on the A SYMMETRY until the graphic at the end. Really quite incredible and super fun construction! Loved so many of the clever clues and gentle back to school vibe with IVIES, TUFTS, ONE L, and COG SCI. TOAD HALL gave me some happy nostalgia ... and led me to read more about Kenneth Grahame, who had quite a hard childhood and difficult life with some crazy events like nearly being killed by a shooter at his day job at a bank (!!) Although he'd written three prior books, The Wind in the Willlows (which was initially panned by some critics!) in 1908 was clearly his best-known work and apparently grew from several bedtime stories he made up for his son. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenneth_Grahame Happy back to school to all!
per 34D, today's earworm, and fashion inspiration https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jhdq_2UAgdQ

Here we go again, me on the outside looking in. I'm one of the few who didn't love this puzzle. First, though I finished it without having to look anything up, I thought it was ridiculously hard for a Tuesday. SALMONBERRY? That's for the west coasters (which I technically am but really am not). COGSCI? ON THE DL? (Not the QT?) (Those are for the younger set). VDAY? (Guess I should have known that, but I didn't). There but for the crosses...

Finally, when I used to solve for speed, I switched to lower case. I solve leisurely now, but still use lower case. It was impossible to see the A progression on paper that way, and I don't appreciate the unfair advantage afforded to app solvers.

Just my three cents.
You can't chop down a symme tree: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rTt1BYwu3wM&list=RDrTt1BYwu3wM&start_radio=1

Crunchy for a Tuesday, as others have noted. A lot of sideways clueing (TREY?). But I liked it fine. 

However, at the risk of courting controversy, I feel a little funny about the constructor‚Äôs notes. I‚Äôm sure tomorrow‚Äôs will be a worthy puzzle and many commenters will praise it. But now, the constructor might be uncertain of whether she earned those comments or if she only got them because her husband asked for them. I wouldn‚Äôt want that, myself. I‚Äôm sure tomorrow‚Äôs constructor‚Äôs merits can stand on their own.

Whew. And Wow! Kind of a tough workout for me with more than a couple of things I was only going to get from working the crosses, but... what an amazing piece of construction. I would think that making any crossword puzzle is a heck of a workout, but the restriction of the placement of all of those a's in the puzzle! (and those were the only ones) - hard to imagine how hard it would be to finally work all that out. 

And... a couple of rather appropriate puzzle finds today, in that they also had unusual tricks. I'll put those in replies.

...

Mini Crossword Rant if I may.
AB*K*A / PSA*K*I - not often you get a really tough natick in the Mini... I've literally never come across either of these. After looking them up it's yet another Jewish food thing, which seem to be way over-represented in NYT crosswords big and small. and a White House adviser from the Obama/Biden era, not a big figure outside the USA in 2025, or even in her let's say "heyday" 10+ years ago.
Solve in seconds, if you're a very specific person. But I assume just constructed by AI - I think you can do better (and often do).

As I get older "My gut says..." a lot of things but never "I'd bet." Should have listened to it when skewing towards asymmetry though. And parsing didn't help. A rare Tuesday fail for me. And can I add my voice to placing a freeze on the use of Oreo, eel, keg, Tati et al including et al as they are in danger of becoming a bit too meh...
I don't know where else to put it so I'll just drop it here: I'm really starting to like the new pips game.

66A. "... parsed as two words (1,8)" threw me. Thought it meant 1A/8A or 1D/8D.
Tues was a TIL-day with 48A. and a few others.
I thought it was a clever puzzle, and thankfully no oreos. I was beginning to think that was a requirement.
chewy little tuesday!!! really enjoyed the reveal at the end! A PLUS
Interesting theme, which I didn't see (or need) while solving the puzzle. Both thematically and otherwise, this one seemed like a Wednesday puzzle to me.

Ah, the pleasure of a stone tablet solve! Saw the "asymmetry" immediately. Found the "A symmetry" on my own after reading the revealer clue. Nothing lights up to give it away. 

Nice one, Kevin.

(I favored QT for ON THE __ , but it was EDEN or ELSE for DL.)

Speaking of asymmetrical grids, the following two are, IMO, the two cutest grids of all time, IMO (and worth a look, dear reader):
‚Ä¢	2/17/15 by Bruce Haight.
‚Ä¢	3/16/22 by Joseph Gangi.

Not trying to be a downer, but I‚Äôve noticed a lot of recent Minis and other NYT games include alcohol references. I don‚Äôt mind them once in a while, but it feels like it‚Äôs been daily lately, and it makes the puzzles less enjoyable for me. I actually stopped after the first question this time.
They misspelled "Woah."
Well, nothing ventured, nothing gained, I guess.
What a fun solve, loved it, looking forward to tomorrow‚Äôs
A Mazing!  Nicely done and thanks.
Understood the first two layers of ASYMMETRY, but only saw the A after the solve. What a lovely Tuesday treat.
For a moment there I thought that the amswer to [Where the sidewalk ends] was BURB...

Kind of chewy for a Tuesday, I had to put it away to finish in the morning, Nice though, I liked it. I never heard of ON THE DL or VDAY in this context or even SALMONBERRY. So there were a few entries entirely missing from my tool set.

This puzzle features a number of things I've never been acquainted with (possibly for a good reason...) aside from the fact that symmetry/asymmetry are a thing that is invisible to me.  Spatial matters just .....don't parse/reveal/excite/matter to me.
VDAY.... hmm.
ECONOMIST...the dismal scientist?
NIECE...though the clue designates a grandchild as written
SALMONBERRY....srsly?  Fruit with fish.  Um...No.
THE DL instead of QT
Well, I guess you had to publish a puzzle today, so why not this one?

At least this time I didn't have to look up ASPER.

I learned my lesson with ATIT, some time ago.

Rolling eyes at self!

Have a good day, everyone. Hope the glorious cooler, drier weather I woke up to is in your neighborhood too.

(second try)

You rascal, you, Kevin Curry. The Times crossword submission guidelines specifically say ‚ÄúCrosswords must have black square symmetry‚Äù. It is what the guidelines call one of the few ‚Äúhard rules‚Äù, rules that are broken ‚Äúwith extreme rarity‚Äù.

Yet you found a way, came up with a theme so novel that they couldn‚Äôt say no. After all, here is a theme that has no theme answers ‚Äì Hah! ‚Äì not to mention that it features symmetry within asymmetry in a way that has never been done before.

Oh, I saw the asymmetry early on, when the design didn‚Äôt fit even some of the rarest symmetries is Crosslandia, but never saw the A factor, and let me tell you, Kevin, when that big A lit up the digital grid upon completion, well, that was a jaw dropper in the best way. (Yes, I am a cross-nerd.)

Thank you, Kevin. You created a classic puzzle that I will remember, possibly for aeons. One of the most brilliant of the year. A bow and a wow, sir!
What a tour de force! Fabulous puzzle, thank you.

Note to future solvers:
Better bring your A-Game!

Concern for paper solvers:
Will they see the Big A?

When I filled in ASYMMETRY, I assumed that the second parsing of the term would simply be "a" different kind of symmetry (not SYMMETRY involving the letter "A").  Had the yellow-A not appeared, I suspect I would have spent a good amount of time looking for some unknown kind of symmetry.
Would I have found it???

The construction was really cool . But.. COGSCI ? Isn't psychology the study of the mind ?? I think cognitive science is a stretch , and as a doc I've never heard it referred to as such -Neuroscience , or Psychology , but not cogsci .
Let me be the first to gratify today's talented constructor by saying I loved tomorrow's puzzle!
Oho! It's a family affair, and Mommy delivers tomorrow! I loved today's puzzle and am eagerly anticipating Wednesday's challenge.

Crossword puzzles: helping us find balance in an off-kilter world.

(nod)
The yellow overlay was a double delight, because I did not see that part of he theme until that popped up. Great start to the day!
May this brilliant puzzle be a small step forward in easing up on black-square symmetry requirements!

AAA, what a good puzzle!

I caught on to the theme when I reached the revealer, and I gasped out loud when I got it. The highlighted A across the grid was icing on a very delicious cake. Thank you to both the constructor and the technical geniuses who made it possible!

Favorite entry: SALMONBERRY. I have played kind of a lot of Stardew Valley, so this fruit is berry familiar to me. (If you play your cards right, a scruffy bear will tell you the secret to picking better berries so you can sell them for more.)
Great puzzle but isn‚Äôt ‚Äúmother‚Äôs daughter‚Äôs daughter‚Äù granddaughter not niece? That would be mother‚Äôs sister‚Äôs daughter, no?

Bravo, Kevin Curry!
If I were grading this crossword puzzle, I think you know what I would give.

Have a great day, everyone.
A+.   Clever, enjoyable, perfect clues and answers for a Tuesday, and a surprise treat at the end.   I saw the symmetry of all the As but did not see that they make an A til the animation.  Fun!
I literally LOL‚Äôd (as the kids say) upon realizing the real meaning of ‚ÄúA Symmetry‚Äù. Thanks!

I have been trying to get a streak fixed after a WiFi issue on Sunday Aug 17 caused my gold result not to be recorded. I have emailed support MULTIPLE times and haven't even received the automated reply indicating that a ticket has been opened. I received one the last time I had a problem (and the problem got fixed within a day). What is going on??
Relatively tough for a Tuesday but satisfying and fun puzzle!
A wonderful surprise! I noticed neither the asymmetry nor the A until the revealer, my last entry. An A Plus!

Impressive! A perfect Tuesday. 

When we first started dating, my husband said we should keep our relationship ‚Äúon the DL‚Äù. He‚Äôs lucky I didn‚Äôt dump him then and there. He changed his mind about that, and we just celebrated 23 years of marriage! Thanks for that memory :)
and I don't think anyone has mentioned that the ONLY A's in the puzzle are the ones in the reveal. Didn't we have a puzzle recently with restricted O's? Another hat tip to the constructor.
Great puzzle! Favorite one in a while!

This took me a bit longer to solve than is my NORM. (Anyone else have terrible getting past the book title when solving that one?) 

I had a bit of difficulty with the southwest corner ‚Äî SALMONBERRY is new to me, PREORDERED was not coming to mind, and ASYMMETRY was one of the last words I filled in. 

How nice that today‚Äôs constructor‚Äôs wife is tomorrow‚Äôs constructor!
Not me crying at the constructors note

I spent too much time looking at the picture accompanying today's Wordplay column, trying to figure out how this image of six women (and two dogs) taking time out from working on a farm in 1918 had anything to do with today's puzzle.

And then I looked at the title of the column "Overall Impact".  Well, what sort of "impact" are these women making?
Think again, X.
All of the women are wearing Overalls!  How impactful!

Thanks for the additional brain teaser, Sam!

Such wonderful cluing on this puzzle! I don't think I've enjoyed the clues so much since, perhaps, the Eugene Maleska days! (That may not be true, but I'm old enough that my memories prefer to go to the back of the stacks). 

I spent more time enjoying the clues than worrying about filling in the answers, so no rushing on this one...just pure enjoyment. Add to that, I have yet to run into a commenter complaining about the puzzle. A miracle? Or, I just haven't read far enough...

Yesterday, during my volunteer shift in the ER, one of our visitors said to me, as I escorted her to visit her husband, "I have to see him before he falls apart. He hasn't finished his Sunday NY Times puzzle, and his week doesn't start until that's done!"

maybe the altitude is messing with my acuity since i arrived in colorado, but i thought today‚Äôs puzzle was more difficult than usual for a tuesday puzzle

a clever construct, happy to see the reveal at the end

happy tuesday, everyone!
I liked this one: lively fill, genius construction, and a fun reveal at the end! Looking forward to his wife‚Äôs puzzle tomorrow!

Delightful in every sense! I loved the clues, and the theme reveal at the very end was a true winner.

I'm looking forward to tomorrow's puzzle!
Very clever. I can‚Äôt wait for your wife‚Äôs puzzle tomorrow.
Terrific puzzle, Kevin.  Not only do I look forward to your wife's offering tomorrow, but - perhaps? - a joint effort down the line!
Great puzzle, Kevin! And I can't wait to see what your wife came up with tomorrow!
In awe of this construction!! What an immense payoff!

Titanomachy. Now that's a five dollar word, but I'm not likely to work it into conversation any time soon. Spoiler Alert! The GODS of Olympus defeat the Titans, and that's when Zeus punishes ATLAS by placing the heavens on his shoulders. Not to be confused with "Clash of the Titans," which was mostly about demi-gods.
Great puzzle!  Did Wednesday come early this week?
Absolutely useless theme.

Ha! What a wild coincidence! Today's my Glu Day at the gym. Gotta stick to your workout plan!

Butt, seriously!
Cool!!!! I'm a sucker for the visuals.
Every time I think I might try my hand at crossword construction I get wowed by a brilliant offering like this, and I scurry back to reality.
Surprisingly tricky for a Tuesday but not complaining. The theme was clever and well executed. I thought PROUDPAPAS  was a bit of a stretch but no quibbles otherwise
Lovely puzzle!
FUN PUZZLE  Thanks!

A symmetry within asymmetry! IDBET that was difficult to construct. Longer than my typical Tuesday, but no complaints. 
SALMONBERRY reminded me of growing up in Washington State and eating them right off the bush, along with huckleberries and blackberries. Great memories. I had no idea they are paired with salmon, and assumed they were named for their color!
That was a really cool puzzle today!  I didn‚Äôt notice the placement of the A‚Äôs until after the highlight appeared, very neat.  Thanks for creating and publishing it.
Great fun for a Tuesday! I didn't expect that!!! Thanks.
What a stylish and well-designed puzzle! Really cool grid and lots of unique, off-kilter clues and entries. Superb! (Felt more like a Wednesday, to be honest, but no complaints from me!)
Amazing; how do they do it.?
Well shoot! Like the Fonz, I can only say 'Ayyyy'!
Pretty darned clever for a Tuesday. Nice puzzle!

You devil, you, Kevin Curry.  The Times crossword submission guidelines specifically say ‚ÄúCrosswords must have black square symmetry‚Äù.  It is what the guidelines call one of the few ‚Äúhard rules‚Äù, rules that are broken ‚Äúwith extreme rarity‚Äù.  

Yet you found a way, came up with a theme so novel that they couldn‚Äôt say no.  After all, here is a theme that has no theme answers ‚Äì Hah! ‚Äì not to mention that it features symmetry within asymmetry in a way that has never been done before. 

Oh, I saw the asymmetry early on, when the design didn‚Äôt fit even some of the rarest symmetries is Crosslandia, but never saw the A factor, and let me tell you, Kevin, when that big A lit up the digital grid upon completion, well, that was a jaw dropper in the best way.  (Yes, I am a cross-nerd.)

Thank you, Kevin.  You created a classic puzzle that I will remember, possibly for aeons.  One of the most brilliant of the year.  A bow and a wow, sir!

Well, for better or worse, after all the "training" here I immediately noticed the little a asymmetry of the grid, and was very happy.  I've long maintained that the symmetry "rule" is plain s__pid and pointless, and deprives the customers of what might otherwise be delightful puzzles based on needless artificial conformity.  Arbitrary counterproductive frippery, based on nothing but convention for its own sake.

On the other hand I missed the intended big A symmetry until the game was complete.  Oh well.  It was still fine.  Fast enjoyable puzzle.

My first entry for [Cutlass] was SEDAN, although I thought that was a bit tricksy for a Tuesday.

Might I have noticed the big A if the online puzzle didn't give me the yellow line as soon as I filled in the last letter? I'm kind of doubtful. We have something similar to a crosswalk (pedestrian crossing) which is the zebra crossing, black and white striped. It is mandatory for the traffic to stop as soon as you step on it. There are not that many of them; at junctions there are traffic lights. 

There are orange flashing lights on each side, called Belisha beacons, named after the Minister of Transport who introduced them. 

A famous zebra crossing is at Abbey Road in London.
@Splat‚Äùtonne‚Äù is not the British spelling of ‚Äúton‚Äù.  A tonne is 1,000 kilograms.  A ton is 2,000 pounds.

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened - first a Wednesday from July 13, 2016 by Tom McCoy. This one was all in the clues and taking a word and turning it into a familiar initialism. Some examples: "Stat shared by many pitchers?" COMMONERA "Leave that lady's tomb alone!" LETERRIP "Exam that's losing popularity in high schools?" DISAPPEARINGACT "Cry from an eager applicant for a delivery job?" PICKMEUPS And there were more. Here's that Xword Info list link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/13/2016&g=34&d=D One more puzzle in another reply. ...

@Rich in Atlanta As threatened again - this is one of strangest puzzles I've ever encountered. Not sure how I would have felt about solving it. Anyway - a Wednesday from October 14, 2015 by Joel Fagliano. Hard to describe. There was one answer at the bottom middle of the puzzle that was completely surrounded by black squares, so there was nothing else crossing it. And there was no clue for it, but it was referenced by a few other clues and answers. Here those are: "Q: ___ / A: There are two, in the third and seventh squares below" DOESITHAVEANN "Q: ___ / A: Indeed, in the fourth square" ISTHEREAG "Q: ___ / A: There's one in the fifth square" IGUESSM "Q: ___ / A: Correct! In the first square" HOWABOUTH "Q: ___ / A: Yes, two, in the second and sixth squares" ANYAS And that separated answer was: HANGMAN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/14/2015&g=20&d=A Weird. ...

@Noemi

Spoilers are fine here. It's expected that you've already done the puzzle and the Mini by the time you get here, or that you're looking for help.

Really, there's no way to discuss a crossword puzzle without discussing the answers.

But spoilers for the non-crossword puzzles, like Connections,or Strands are not wanted here. And they have their own, separate comment boards.

@Alex
Millions of people not Jewish or from NYC, but who have watched Seinfeld, have heard of Chocalete BABKA.

@Alex I think if you have never lived near New York City it may be hard to understand how NYC culture is infused and melded with Jewish culture. There are a lot of Jewish delis and NYC people of all cultures have come to adore (or be familiar with) all kinds of Jewish foods with some being more mainstream than others, but they are ubiquitous. Same thing with Yiddish phrases, they are used often and freely in this area of the country. So it's a grey area where Jewish culture ends and NYC culture begins. I'm not Jewish but living in or near NY you become steeped in the culture and assimilate it. Just an explanation for our non American friends.
